YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S
SPEECH
Debate on the Address
(Second Day)


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Question [14th December, 1965],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to: -

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of Singapore express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present Session of this Assembly.".'. ---- [The Prime Minister].

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Speaker: The debate can now resume.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, the policy speech delivered by His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in this House has enumerated the new policies and programmes for our nation-building. All these programmes and policies represent a challenge. They outline our aims and tasks for nation-building, that is, to build a multi-racial, democratic socialist society which is fair and just. The task of nation-building is not of the Government alone. It is also the task of all patriotic citizens. All people should be mobilised.

Column: 149



    The opening of the present Session is a new page in the history of Singapore. It has ushered in a new era in the history of Singapore as an independent and sovereign country. It has ushered in an era in which we should all contribute our best towards building a prosperous and happy nation. What is regrettable is that when such an era is being ushered in, the Barisan Sosialis Members are not sharing our sentiments and the sentiments of the people when they resort to boycotting this Session or Parliament. This is understandable from their philosophy - subversion against our nation. We condemn the Barisan Sosialis action in boycotting the Parliament and in resorting to anti-national activities. As Assemblymen elected by the people, their basic duty is to speak for the people and to voice the intentions and the will of the people in this House. Yet they have gone out of their way to say that our independence is phoney and that our sovereignty is only superficial. More than 100 nations throughout the world have recognised in as an independent and sovereign country, although ours is a small country. This can be seen from the keen welcome extended to our Goodwill Mission to Afro-Asian countries led by our Deputy Prime Minister, Dr Toh Chin Chye. The talk by the Barisan Sosialis that Singapore's independence is false should be condemned by all the people of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, what has made the case of the Barisan Sosialis so sad is the Fact that the people have not paid any attention to their shouting of slogans. Their boycott has caused no surprise because all the people have come to realise that their performance and the shouting of slogans that Singapore is a neo-colonialist country created by an imperialist plot have been seen through by the people. Now the people are discerning. In the end, in the course of history, such a hunch of political adventurers will be buried by the overwhelming strength of the people.

    The task ahead of us is to build a multi-racial, multi-lingual, multi-cultural, multi-religious society - fair and just - in which everybody can get

Column: 150

a fair share of the facilities and benefits offered by the country and where nobody will he discriminated against by others. This has all along been our objective, in fact, since 1959 when our Party came to power. This policy has been implemented ever since we have been in power. It is the one best fitted to the multi-racial character of our society. The intelligent leadership and policy of the Government have rallied the people closer together. They have set an objective for all the people to strive for. All patriotic citizens should seize this opportunity to do their best in this work of nation-building. This policy is the only correct one that can lead our country towards a happy and prosperous society.

    Although the Chinese are the majority in Singapore, our policy is based on multi-racialism. This is the basis of our policy in nation building. We have recognised Malay, Chinese, Tamil and English as the four official languages, with Malay as the common national language. In fact, this humane and correct policy will not only bring about prosperity and stability to our nation, but it is also one that has the popular support of the people. From this we can see that the policy of nation-building based on multi-racialism is one that is acceptable to all. It is the only correct one. It is also a humanitarian policy which can lead to the happiness and prosperity of our country. In Switzerland, where the same policy is pursued, we also see peace and happiness. The events in Rhodesia and South Africa and in some other countries, on the contrary, are not very enviable for us to emulate. There is discrimination in those countries. They are in a state of turmoil and we can see sanguinary fratricidal activities going on there. We want to remind the racial extremists of such racial inequality and the tragedy that is taking place there. They should reconsider their attitude. They should open their eyes wide and see what is taking place in South Africa, Rhodesia and Cyprus where there are racial disturbances. These conflicts are a great tragedy.

Column: 151



    Mr Speaker. I shall now touch on the Five-Year Plan as contained in the policy speech of the Yang di- Pertuan Negara. The task ahead is for a peaceful reformation of our society. After seven years of continuous improvements in building and construction, we have achieved certain objectives. These achievements have won the general applause of international circles. They have acclaimed our achievements. Even our Minister for Finance, Mr Lim Kim San, was acknowledged for his meritorious service in nation-building by being presented with the Magsaysay Award.

    This policy is good for our society. Under this policy a high living standard for our people has been brought about. From 1961-64 we implemented the first Five-Year Plan. We spent about $870 million in economic development, housing, industrial development, public administration, social services, and other services which have given a great impetus to the progress of Singapore. From 1961 there have been annual increases in revenue and expenditure on development is also increasing. In 1961 the sum was $230 million, and in 1964 it was $280 million. There was an increase of 7 per cent. Additional sums are to he allotted for the additional one year to the First Plan. Large sums have again been allotted for the next Five-Year Plan which will he used for social reforms, housing, urban redevelopment and industrialisation which will create more opportunities of employment, and which will lead to the modernisation of our City State. Undoubtedly this Five-Year Development Plan can be expected to succeed. This will further raise the standard of living of our people who are already enjoying a comfortable standard of living, just as what was said in the policy speech.

    British bases now in Singapore are only a temporary measure for our own defence. Therefore, our Government is contemplating the implementation of a volunteer force in order to defend our country. No matter how the Barisan Sosialis and their stooges boycott us, the people will pay no heed to such foolish antics.

Column: 152



    These measures strongly reflect the fact that our nation is recognised as one having a good standing. The people understand very well that it is the duty of everybody to contribute his bit to the continued progress of his country. For that purpose, all the people should volunteer to join the People's Forces in order to defend our country, so that we may survive. There is a Chinese saying that it is the duty of every citizen to see that his nation exists, and this kind of patriotic act is the surest guarantee of our continued survival and the existence of our nation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this newly independent country of ours has given all the people new tasks to perform in order to build a model country in which all races will have equal status. The minority races will have special safeguards in the Constitution. Everybody can play his part in nation-building. Every able-bodied person and youth should brace himself for the task of nation-building and render his services to the country to the best of his ability, whether it is in the fields of commerce, education, agriculture, defence, or in any other field of human activity. Everyone can contribute his hit to enable the country to march forward to become a modernised and highly industrialised country which will bring about an affluent society for all the two million people of Singapore --- a new model society.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for his speech, and I support the motion.

2.53 p.m.

    Mr S. Rajoo (Farrer Park)(In Tamil): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the First Parliament of independent Singapore, and I join my friends in thanking the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for his Address delivered in this House. In his Address, the Yang di-Pertuan Negara has said that equal treatment will he given to all races and all language streams, and also that a Commission will be appointed to look into the rights of the minority races and to find .out their problems. No country in the world has only one race for its population. At one time or other different races have

Column: 153

lived in these countries and different cultures put into practice. Finally, as the days go by, all these different cultures are integrated and become one. For example, take Russia or the United States of America. In these countries there are people who speak many languages and who belong to many races. Countries in Asia, Africa and Europe are no exception either. We can even take our neighbours, Malaysia and Indonesia. They have people of different races and of different cultures. It is also the case with Singapore, which now has attained full independence. It has got a multi-racial population. We, the Government, can put into practice proper programmes and adopt a policy of mutual understanding and tolerance. By these policies, we can have a nation of peaceful co-existence.

    Singapore is a small island and our people have to depend on trade. We have to admit that we are enjoying a high standard of living and, at the same time, our population is increasing. So the Government has a duty to increase the facilities for the people. In education, housing, and in the industrial field, we have achieved progress through our first Five-Year Plan. At the same time when we talk about our progress, we have also to look into the defects. The Government has to find out the defects and work out remedies.

    There is a Tamil secondary school in Singapore. It is the only Tamil secondary school and is called the Umar Pulavar Secondary School. The children who leave it after completing their studies are not able to get equal opportunities for jobs in Government departments. If the reason for this is the lower standard of education in this school, the Government should find out the defects and, if necessary, introduce a new syllabus, thereby giving such school-leavers equal preference with children who leave schools in other streams.

    Our housing programme is praiseworthy. But the Housing Board is adopting certain policies which are not practicable. For example, take a family of two boys, two girls, and a mother. They take a Housing Board flat

Column: 154

under the name of one of the boys and live for 15 years. As the days go by, the two boys are married, and one of them is quick enough to buy a house through a loan from the Government. Since the Housing Board flat was acquired through him, he writes a letter to the Board saying that he has bought a house and requesting the Board to change the tenancy to his brother who is going to live there. But the Board says, "According to our rules, if a tenant buys a house of his own, he has to vacate the fiat as a whole with his family." "This is impossible," says the tenant. "I can move into my own house only with my wife and children. I can't take the whole family in, my brother and my mother." But the Board argues that they can change the tenancy only under two conditions - one is should the tenant die, and the other should the tenant leave the country. Other than these two conditions, they will not change the tenancy to any other person. So we have certain rules which are not practicable, and I request the Board to change them, so that they could he put into practice and help to raise the standard of living of our people.

    Next, I wish to touch on foreign policy. We are adopting a non-aligned policy in our foreign affairs. This was stated by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara. For example, we are friendly with our neighbouring countries and we show our goodwill to them. This is our desire. This is important for the progress of our people and country as a whole. Now we are in an atomic age, and we can only survive if we adopt a neutral policy. Afro-Asian countries and India are adopting such a policy. Our Government has adopted it in world politics. It will be independent in such policies. If we put into practice our policies, we show no partiality towards West or East. We are not bound by any of these countries. In our foreign policy as regards Vietnam and the Indo-Pakistani conflict, we are neutral and we closely go with the Afro-Asian countries. By adopting this policy, we can create more opportunities for the trade of our

Column: 155

country. Most of our people depend on trade and industries for their livelihood.

    In the Jurong industrial complex, there are many factories coming up and more goods are being produced. We have to search for outside markets for these products. There is no Common Market going to be established with Malaysia, so we have to find external markets for the good of our people. We have to live, so the only way is to have a neutral policy with all the countries and establish trade relations with countries like America, Russia and so on.

    Recently, our Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister and the State Minister for Education went on a tour. A good reception was given to them. This reflects the correctness of our policy. Next year we are going to send trade missions to different countries. This shows our victory in this field.

    The Barisan are boycotting this Parliament now. They say we should be friendly with Afro-Asian countries. In fact, we are friendly with Afro-Asian countries. Not only that, but we go even beyond that. We are adopting the neutral policy of these countries and I would like to tell these people this, in fact, it is the Barisan who adopt a particular group policy. They say that we should he friendly with Afro-Asian countries but they do not have the foresight of the Afro-Asian countries.

    Singapore has been accepted as an independent country by the United Nations. When our delegation went to the Afro-Asian countries to explain our independence, they respected the independence of Singapore and gave a red carpet welcome to the delegation. But the Barisan here are boycotting the Session of this Parliament. This shows how defunct they are in their policies. They do not know how to respect their own country's independence. They do not understand the independence of their own country. I say to them that they should learn from the Afro-Asian countries to respect Singapore's independence. We are trying to he friendly with Indonesia, our biggest neighbour. We are

Column: 156

prepared to sell to Indonesia, which needs them urgently, food and medicine. Recently the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Subandrio, has expressed his desire to have talks with Singapore. In future, there is an opportunity for better relationship between the peoples of both the territories. One day Indonesia and Peking will realise the status of our independent country. When that time conies, I do not know where the Barisan will go and hide themselves. Our foreign policy will always take into account not only the welfare of our people hut also the welfare of the people in Malaysia.

3.07 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Culture (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, we are indeed very grateful for the opportunity to he here today to express our thanks to His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for his Address at the opening of the present Session of this House. Grateful indeed we ought to be for our very presence here, for the political developments in the last two years --- two very eventful years --- took such a rapid and rigid course that even the then Central Government contemplated repressive measures which were openly admitted without reserve by the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Prince Abdul Rahman, on the day we became independent.

    Sir, I do not know whether we can regard ourselves as unfortunate, for we happened to assume the role of speaking the minds of the people and, therefore, we were supposed to be the ones that were repressed. But one thing we are fortunate in - and I think the people across the Causeway should also share in it --- is that these repressive measures never became a reality. Because if they did, then it would throw the whole country into chaos and confusion, and the existence of this House and the Members here would have become a mockery of democracy, a term which has a different connotation in the minds of both the feudal reactionaries ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have indicated to the House that that is a line which the Chair will not accept.

Column: 157



    Mr Fong Sip Chee: The term "democracy" has a different connotation in the minds of the communalists and the Communists.

    Sir, the intensity of the political struggle between the P.A.P. and the ultra-communalists in the last two years was not only a bitter battle to win and capture the hearts and minds of the people for our survival alone, but was also a conflict of the basic political philosophy between the Right-wing and the progressive democratic Socialists, in our way, we believe that we can succeed and we have succeeded to a very large extent in proving to the people that our method is the best alternative in achieving a better deal in life for the people.

    Sir, in whatever direction the political development in our country may take, we, the P.A.P., are always alive to the challenges that confront us from time to time; and for these challenges, we sought for and obtained new approaches and new solutions. In this gruelling struggle, we have never lost sight of our objectives and obligations to the people of Singapore, i.e., to build, in the course of five, ten or even 20 years, a multi-racial society founded upon the principles of democratic socialism. We are caught, as in every developing country in the world, in a dilemma; that is, in our political approaches, the Government must be ideological and as pragmatic in its administration. There are some political Parties which cannot adopt a fixed political ideology for their party lines. Some political Parties are openly anti-Communist and, at the same time, resist the idea of socialism, for it was branded as a foreign ideology. And at the same time, they refuse to be called capitalists. So if they are anti-Communists, reject socialism and refuse to be called capitalists, what are they?

    Sir, the struggle was in fact the result of rising fear of the traditionalists. It was the fear of progress, the fear of new ideas, the fear of a better deal for the people, the fear of a better alternative which inevitably must result in higher demands and expectations from the people. For us, these demands and

Column: 158

expectations are to be welcomed, because we believe it is only with the political sophistication and maturity of the people that a nation can survive and progress. We can afford to make this statement because, with our determination, our dedication and our dynamism which is so apparently absent in the leadership in the neighbouring countries, we can meet, to a fairly adequate extent, the immediate and the long-term requirements of our people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, to the traditionalists, our progress and achievements must be resisted and halted. But they were not the only ones who were envious and frightened of our success. For the Communists and the pro-Communist Barisan Sosialis, our success would mean that the democratic socialist way in nation-building was far better than the Communist-Marxist idea of armed revolution - that destruction must necessarily be a prelude to construction. En all these struggles, the Communists and the front-line expendables in the Barisan Sosialis found themselves in a state of complete indecisiveness and, therefore, inspiration would have to be sought from somewhere outside Singapore. But this inspiration was not forthcoming and neither was this arrangement satisfactory because, at this very moment, the two reluctant Members of the Barisan Sosialis, the Member for Nee Soon and the Member for Toa Payoh are now being chased from pillar to post by the anti-Communist army quite near to Singapore.

    Sir, our struggle in the last two years can be generalised into two fronts. On the one hand, the ideological front and, on the other, the pragmatic front. The temporary impotency of the Communists and the Barisan Sosialis gave us good time and a good opportunity to concentrate our efforts in our fight with the communalists and the traditionalists. For the P.A.P. in Singapore, politically our base has been secured. And to the Communalists, there is only one avenue open to them. They know that politically they can never control Singapore. Our people with progressive ideas, our people with higher demands, require

Column: 159

an administration that will bring better results. Therefore, the political arena of Singapore was totally hostile to them. And, therefore, the only avenue left to them was by way of economic strangulation.

    Sir, I do not wish to touch on the pros and cons of Malaysia. I personally feel that the concept and the basic principles which brought about Malaysia are still valid at this very moment. However, when we were a member in Malaysia, as I said earlier, our progress was not to be tolerated. And in this action, they paid a high price - turnover tax, crown cork tax, profit tax and a whole host of others - at the expense of even the sufferings of their own people - our people. Sir, in sentiment, I cannot regard the people across the Causeway as a separate people. And they introduced all these taxes even knowing full well that their own people would suffer.

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the Member is referring to present measures taken by the Malaysian Parliament, he is completely out of order.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, I was referring to the taxes imposed while we were a member in a larger family.

    Mr Speaker: Then the Member is in order.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: And just because we criticised the undesirability of these taxes, we were branded as subversive. Now that Singapore is no longer a member State of a greater family, Malaysia, all these taxes were dropped for they are no longer valid and useful with the P.A.P. now confined and localised to a small island of 224 square miles.

    Sir, independence on the 9th of August caught both the Right-wing and the Communists by surprise. For the Barisan Sosialis, new instructions could not reach them in time and they are now facing a three-level split, a split in the higher leadership, as acknowledged by Mr Lim Ching Siong that Singapore's independence is genuine and

Column: 160

that they must accept the situation and channel and redirect their struggle within an independent nation. Another split is among the front-line expendables, that is, the present Barisan Sosialis leadership - third-class heroes they are - that Singapore's independence is phoney, and for that matter they must boycott Parliament sittings and even elections. But some Members of the Barisan Sosialis may be more practical, for even at this moment when they are boycotting Parliament, the usual allowance will still go to them and they will accept them with open and willing hands.

    Sir, they are now caught in a dilemma, as was the case with the M.C.P. in the year 1957, whether or not to acknowledge the Pan-Malayan Independence, with Singapore's independence - and the Right-wing also found themselves in difficulties, some of them in respect of their livelihood. For example - I would ask your guidance, Mr Speaker, if I am allowed to refer to a former Chief Minister of this House - a former Chief Minister from 1955 to 1959 who said that he was the only saviour for the people of Singapore and that Singapore was his only country. So many good words had been uttered, so many good things had been said, but two or three days after independence, he found himself forsaking the people of Singapore and willingly accepting the citizenship of another country. Does it mean that within two days, he suddenly lost his love for the people of Singapore, after so many good things had been said? He is now enjoying a good position as a High Commissioner for a foreign country. Sir, "loyalty" is a very abstract term. As I have said, to the Communists, to the Right-wing and to us, it might mean different things, but definitely it does not mean that if one's rice bowl were to be broken tomorrow or next week, lie therefore would forsake his citizenship and loyalty, would assume citizenship of another country, and would pledge his allegiance to another country.

    Ours is an open society. We prefer and we believe in open argument, a frank expression of ideas and opinions.

Column: 161



    This House itself is a public forum for the elected representatives of the people to come and voice the grievances of the people they represent. In the ten years from 1955 to 1965 - and from 1959, the first time the P.A.P. came to power up to the present time - we have fought the colonialists, the Communists, the Right-wing opportunists, the communalists and the feudalists and even a combination of some of them, as we have seen in the Hong Lim by-election. Sir, the Hong Lim by-election could have probably changed the entire course of history of Singapore. Had the P.A.P. lost the Hong Lim by-election, then I would say, as I have said earlier, that it might have led to repressive measures, and therefore the existence of this House would no longer be regarded as useful. However, each phase and each struggle gave us new strength, dedication and renewed conviction in our beliefs, and I do not believe that any amount of suppression, threats, such as one voice, one race and one religion, meaningless demonstrations by the Barisan Sosialis and bomb explosions or even race riots - we experienced two race riots in 1964 - can deter us from our set course to nationhood. We do not submit to any intimidation.

    Sir, with independence, we are now faced with a heavier burden, but we can bear it. In three years' time, Singapore will prosper. In the short period of three to five years, we will set the right foundation for our new nation. We do not ask for anything more than the right of our people to determine our own destiny and to live our own way of life, unmolested and unhindered by anybody in this region. We are small in every respect, in terms of population, area, natural resources and, therefore, we have no capacity to attack others, and it is not our intention to do so, but we must have the capacity to prevent others from attacking us. On the other hand, we cannot bear the tremendous expense of raising and maintaining a full-scale army and, therefore, we have the idea of building up a big people's force, a volunteer army. As the Prime Minister has said, the world does not owe us a living, and we also do not

Column: 162

owe the world a living. We want to be friends with all. The friends of another country may be our friends too, but the enemy of another country may not necessarily be regarded as our enemy. To those who have a special and vested interest in the political stability of this region, I say that they really have something to ponder on. But it would be naive for us to believe that we can survive on our own without subjecting ourselves to the influence and development of neighbouring countries, it is in our interest that we wish to see Malaysia succeed and prosper, because we believe that if a volcano erupts 250 miles away in Kuala Lumpur, the lava will come down to Singapore, but that does not mean that we will beg for our survival on bended knees. And to those who think they can sink us by hostile acts, we say, "Think again," because Singapore will not be the only one to sink. In this sinking ship, you carry along the entire feudal system, the entire old social order. But whatever happens, Singapore is bound to be a catalyst that will start a chain reaction throughout this region, whether for prosperity or for chaos. If we succeed, so will this region. If we fail, then I say that those who have special interests in this region will have to sit down and recalculate their obligations in this area.

    Sir, in our foreign policy, we have adopted a non-aligned stand and I am given to understand that there is a motion in the House in the name of a Barisan Sosialis Member to urge the Government to be friendly with Afro-Asian countries.
